case_name: Hari alias Dada Khemu Gawali v. State of Bombay

facts.text: Petition No. 272 of 1955 filed under Article 32 of the Constitution challenging vires of Bombay Police Act, 1951 section 57.

anchor.surface_text: ORIGINAL JURISDICTION Petition No. 272 of 1955. Petition under. Article 32 of the Constitution of India for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

facts.text: Externment order dated 8th November 1954 passed against petitioner by Deputy Commissioner of Police, Crime Branch C.I.D., Greater Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: the externment order dated the 8th November 1954 was passed against the petitioner by the first respondent, the Deputy Commissioner of Police, Crime Branch  1 , C.I.D., Greater Bombay.

facts.text: Second respondent is the State of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The second respondent is the State of Bombay.

facts.text: Petitioner is citizen of India, born in Bombay, residing in quarters of City of Bombay, owns bullock carts for transport and company for selling milk.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner, who claims to be a citizen of India, was born in Bombay and had been, before the order of externment in question, residing in one of the quarters of the City of Bombay.

facts.text: Prohibition Police instituted twelve prohibition cases against petitioner, all ended in discharge or acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner alleges that the Prohibition Police of the City instituted twelve prohibition cases against him which all ended either in his discharge or acquittal.

facts.text: Externment order passed against petitioner in August 1950, set aside by Government in December 1950 on appeal.

anchor.surface_text: An externment order was passed against him in August 1950. That order was set aside by the Government in December 1950, on appeal by the petitioner.

facts.text: Detention order passed against petitioner in December 1953 under Preventive Detention Act, 1950, detained in Thana District prison.

anchor.surface_text: In December 1953 an order of detention was passed against him under the Preventive Detention Act, 1950, and he was detained in the Thana District prison.

facts.text: Petitioner moved High Court of Bombay under Article 226 against detention order, released before hearing.

anchor.surface_text: He moved the High Court of Bombay under article 226 of the Constitution against the said order of detention.- He was released from detention before the said petition was actually heard by the High Court.

facts.text: Petitioner charged with possession of liquor, discharged by Presidency Magistrate on 24th February 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the petitioner along with others was charged with possession of liquor. The case went on for about two years when he was ultimately discharged by the Presidency Magistrate on the 24th February 1955

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on night of 9th October 1954 with companions by Ghost Squad after midnight, alleged running away on sight of police van, chased and arrested, found in possession of knives and weapons.

anchor.surface_text: On the night of the 9th October 1954 the petitioner was arrested along with his companypanions a little after midnight by members of the police force designated Ghost Squad, which was a special wing of the Crime Branch of the C.I.D.,

facts.text: Notice served on petitioner in October 1954 under section 57 read with section 59 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In October 1954 the petitioner was served with a numberice under section 57 read with section 59 of the Act.

facts.text: Petitioner convicted on 14-10-1938 under sections 304/109 IPC for 6 years RI and 324/109 IPC for 2 years RI concurrently by H.C.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on 2-5-1948 in connection with Nagpada P.S.C.R. No. 353 u/s 143,144,146,147,148,149,324 IPC, discharged for want of evidence.

facts.text: Petitioner arrested on 9-10-1954 at 12:50 a.m. with 7 others, armed with clasp knives, iron bar, lathi.

anchor.surface_text: That number you have been arrested on 9-10-1954 at about 12-50 a.m. in the companypany of 7 others, viz. Amir Masud  2  Francis Sherao China  3  Antoo Narayan Abdul Wahab Abdul Gafoor  5  Laxman Rama

facts.text: Petitioner appeared before Superintendent on 8th November 1954 with counsel, filed written petition Ex. B, accepted correctness of first paragraph of notice, denied other allegations.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner appeared before the Superintendent on the 8th November 1954 with his companynsel and filed a long petition companytaining allegations running into 16 paragraphs showing cause against the order of externment

facts.text: Externment order Ex. C passed on 8th November 1954 directing petitioner to remove outside Greater Bombay for two years after pending case.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent aforesaid ultimately passed the order of externment which is Exhibit C to the petition, on the 8th November 1954. After reciting the previous companyviction

facts.text: Petitioner preferred appeal to Government of Bombay against externment order, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner preferred an appeal to the Government of Bombay against the said order of externment. But the appeal was dismissed.

facts.text: In conviction of 1938, petitioner and brother Rajaram found guilty of causing death of person who gave evidence against them.

anchor.surface_text: It is further stated in the affidavit that in the previous case in which the petitioner had been companyvicted be bad been found guilty along with his brother Rajaram of having caused the death of a person who had given evidence

facts.text: Petitioner arrested March 1948, police constable assaulted, not charge-sheeted due to insufficient evidence.

anchor.surface_text: namely- In March 1948 a police companystable was assaulted. Though the petitioner was one of the persons companycerned with the crime, he was number charge-sheeted because sufficient evidence was number forthcoming against him.

facts.text: April 1948, petitioner's brother charged him and others with throwing sodawater bottles and using lathis, discharged for want of evidence.

anchor.surface_text: In April 1948 the petitioners brother had charged him and eight others with having thrown sodawater bottles and used lathis. The Presidency Magistrate, 17th Court, Mazgaon, Bombay,

facts.text: May 1949, petitioner and others rescued arrested persons including brother Rajaram from police custody, case failed August 1950 due to witnesses not turning up.

anchor.surface_text: In May 1949 the police had- arrested three persons including Rajaram aforesaid, the petitioners brother for being companycerned in sale of illicit liquor. While those arrested persons were being taken to the police lorry

facts.text: On 9th October 1954 at 12:50 a.m., Special Squad noticed petitioner and seven others armed, running away, chased and arrested, found with clasp knives, smelling of alcohol.

anchor.surface_text: At about 12-50 a.m. on 9th October 1954, the Special Squad, Crime Branch, C.I.D., Bombay, while proceeding on their rounds numbericed the petitioner and seven others armed with an iron bar and lathi.

facts.text: Petitioner placed on trial under Bombay Prohibition Act and Bombay Police Act after October 1954 arrest, acquitted due to discrepancies in prosecution evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was placed on his trial for offences under the Bombay Prohibition Act and the Bombay Police Act. He was acquitted by the learned trial Judge because of discrepancies in the evidence of some of the prosecution witnesses.

holdings.text: Section 57 of the Bombay Police Act does not contravene Article 19(1)(d) and (e); the restrictions imposed are reasonable under Article 19(5) in the interests of the general public.

anchor.surface_text: Article 19 of the Constitution has guaranteed the several rights enumerated under that article to all citizens of India. After laying down the different rights to freedom in clause 1 , clauses  2  to  6

holdings.reasoning_summary: Balances individual freedom of movement/residence against public interest in preventing repeat offences by convicted criminals; preventive measure justified as dispersal of gangs; applies precedents like Gurbachan Singh.

holdings.text: No authority under section 57 can direct externment from the entire State of Bombay; power limited to local jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: Now the only question is whether the provisions of the impugned section are number justified in the larger interest of the companymunity, or, in other words, whether they impose a larger

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language limits to 'area within local limits of his jurisdiction'; aimed at gang dispersal, not statewide ban.

holdings.text: No provision for Advisory Board required for section 57; distinguished from preventive detention under Article 22(4).

anchor.surface_text: The very fact that the Constitution in article 22(4) has made specific provision for an Advisory Board

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article 22(4) specific to detention; Article 19 restrictions need not mirror; precedents like Khare and VG Row uphold without binding board.

holdings.text: Procedure under section 59 satisfies natural justice; police not acting as prosecutor and judge.

anchor.surface_text: reference has to be made to the provisions of section 59 of the Act It provides that before action is taken under sections 55, 56 or 57

holdings.reasoning_summary: Notice of allegations, opportunity to explain/adduce evidence/representation by counsel; higher officers decide based on preventive role, not prosecution.

holdings.text: Clubbing of offences in section 57(a) (Chapters XII, XVI, XVII IPC) valid as matter of legislative wisdom.

anchor.surface_text: Chapter XVI contains section 299 to section 377 and Chapter XVII contains section 378 to section 462 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide range but not unreasonable for preventive purpose; court defers to legislature unless clearly arbitrary.

holdings.text: Right of appeal under section 60 to State Government not illusory.

anchor.surface_text: right of appeal to the State Government conferred by section 60 of the Act are illusory

holdings.reasoning_summary: State expected to review with due care; supplemented by section 61 judicial review.

holdings.text: Section 61 provides adequate judicial safeguard against arbitrary orders under section 57.

anchor.surface_text: Section 61 has provided a further safeguard to a person dealt with under section 57 by providing that though an order passed

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited grounds for challenge: procedural non-compliance, no material, no witness unwillingness opinion; suitable for preventive context where witnesses fear.

holdings.text: Previous orders of discharge or acquittal can be taken into account for subjective satisfaction under section 57.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be laid down as a general proposition of law that a previous order of discharge or acquittal cannot be taken into account

holdings.reasoning_summary: May indicate witness intimidation/non-availability; not objective trial but preventive satisfaction; materials here show pattern.

holdings.text: The externment order against petitioner valid; no grounds to quash.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons aforesaid, in our opinion, numbergrounds have been made out for issuing any writ or direction to the authorities companycerned or for quashing the orders impugned. The application is therefore dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Previous conviction under Ch XVI IPC; multiple incidents show likely repetition despite discharges; bona fides not questioned.

holdings.text: Section 57(a) of Bombay Police Act constitutionally invalid; imposes unreasonable restrictions on Art 19(1)(d)(e).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Wide offences without seriousness/time/witness unavailability limits; unlike s.56; no rational nexus to public interest; departs from CrPC preventives.
